content:
Although cytochalasin prevents cytokinesis, it does not stop
nuclear divisions. Fertilize some Ciona eggs. When they reach
the 2-cell Stage place some in a (provided) cytochalasin solution.
You will be able to watch the nuclei dividing under your compound
microscopes during the next hour.
5. Metamorphosis of the ascidian larva
You will be provided with some attractive orange colonies of a
colonial ascidian, digense. This Southern California
species is now endemic in Cape waters as a marine fouling
organism: it has been given the common name of Freeman's Blight in
honor of Gary Freeman, who first released it into Eel Pond about
15 years ago.
If you tease these colonies apart with needles, you will release
some very large and interesting orange larvae. The species has a
form of development in which large eggs are sequestered and
nurtured in brood pouches; they release larvae (at dawn) rather
than form of development called viviparous. The larvae
look like small Hoover vacuum cleaners. While they are
unfortuntely quite opaque, they start to undergo metamorphosis
quickly (within 20 minutes) and are extremely hardy. While these
larvae are unfortunately relatively opaque, you can nonetheless
see many features of their metamorphosis. Watch the process of
larval tail resorption: it happens fast. Isolate some of the
larvae into clean sea water dishes (before they metamorphose) and
you will find small zooids in your dishes tomorrow.
